newsitem.title: RUSSIA: Russian shares close mixed but market weak-traders.
newsitem.headline: Russian shares close mixed but market weak-traders.

text.p: Russian shares closed mixed on Tuesday, and traders said the market felt weak and expected prices to drift lower in the near future.
"The last week and a half has had good economic and political news and the market has done nothing," said a senior Western trader.
"When a previously strong market reacts poorly to good economic news that usually presages a sell-off, and that is what is happening. You name it, you can buy it."
The Russian Trading System 23-shares lost 0.11 percent to close at 330.01. A year ago it hit its record low, 66.69.
UES EESR.RTS, a recent favourite among foreign investors, eased to $0.2220 from $0.2260 at Monday's close. Chelyabenergo CHNG.RTS fell to $0.450 from $0.480.

Automaker Gaz GAZA.RTS shot up to $40.00 from $33.10 after Boris Nemtsov, governor of Nizhny Novgorod region where Gaz is located and newly-appointed First Deputy Prime Minister, said bureaucrats would have to drive domestic vehicles.
President Boris Yeltsin is in the process of forming a new government.
Some traders blamed shareholder meetings for a pause in the market, but said they were generally puzzled by its failure to move.

Peter Kizenko, chief trader at ING Barings, said the fact that economic indicators showing a growing economy had been questioned by some economists was troubling. He said the market would likely be quiet for a few more weeks.
"People want to see how the new cabinet takes its first steps," he said. "If it does not stumble, we should be geared for a fourth consecutive summer rally."
Trinfiko trader Ilya Galtsov said operators were not expecting anything special from the upcoming summit between Yeltsin and U.S. President Bill Clinton, scheduled for Thursday in Helsinki.
